Award.AwardTitle: The Bioscience Scholars Program: Bringing the Master's Degree Within Reach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The intellectual merit of this project, Bioscience Scholars (BioS) at the University of Florida, stems from its goal of bringing a thesis-based BS/MS program within reach of low-income students, making the scientific profession and its community accessible to them and allowing them to achieve their maximum potential. The project targets students in a statewide high school biotechnology program who have already demonstrated an interest in biotechnology and acquired substantial technical skills, but lack the financial resources to complete a graduate degree. Scholars are provided coursework and workshops focused on foundational knowledge, critical thinking skills and technical skills, and are given the opportunity for extensive, mentored research experience. The BioS program leverages an institutional commitment so that scholars graduate with a combined BS/MS degree within five years.

Broader impacts include curricular reforms that affect all biology students at the University of Florida, not just the scholars. This program could serve as a national model of creating diversity because the targeted population from which students are recruited includes many underrepresented minority students. Finally, students in this program are trained to fill local needs in the job market in Florida's rapidly growing biotechnology sector.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Florida S-STEM Bioscience Scholars (BioS) program ran from 2013 to 2020, admitting new students from 2014 to 2018. The program objectives were to recruit highly skilled, highly motivated and academically-talented students who were also financially-needy, support them in obtaining a BS degree and, optionally, an MS degree in a structured, supportive five-year program, and assist them in continuing after graduation to careers in the life sciences industry or doctoral programs. Scholars were typically placed in their first year with a faculty research mentor, and continued participating in research every semester until graduation. As part of their participation in the program, the scholars received cross-disciplinary training in STEM concepts and skills; training in responsible conduct of research, laboratory safety, animal care and use (when indicated); exposure to the role of research in academia and industry; and exposure to regulatory issues associated with research in the public and private sectors. During their undergraduate years, the program provided each scholar with up to $10,000/yr in scholarship funds, depending on their unmet financial aid need as determined from the FAFSA.

The program admitted 13 scholars with the following demographics: 13 (all) financially disadvantaged, 10 female, 8 underrepresented minority, 11 freshman admits, one rising junior admit, and one rising senior admit. Of the 13 total scholars recruited, 11 were retained in the program (one was terminated from the program the other one left the program after one semester).

All 13 scholars either graduated (8) or are currently in their senior year (5) and are on-track to graduate this academic year. All scholars were prepared and encouraged to combine their BS degree with a fifth year for a thesis-based MS degree. Of the eight scholars who have already graduated with a BS degree, five continued to the MS degree. Two of these completed the MS degree within the additional year and continued to competitive PhD programs at other institutions (Yale and Cornell), two scholars left their MS program before completion (and subsequently obtained employment in the sciences as a lab technician and a zoo technician), one scholar has been admitted to an MS program to begin in Fall 2020, one scholar (who is still an undergraduate) has been admitted to an MS program to begin in spring 2021, and one scholar (who is still an undergraduate) plans to apply to the MS program in fall 2020.Of the three scholars who have already graduated with a BS degree but did not continue to the MS program, one is a research scientist in the biotechnology industry, one is in medical school, and one (the student who left the program) is planning to apply to medical school.

The program at UF stimulated the institutionalization of research-intensive, five-year BS/MS degree programs between the Biology BS degree program and the MS degree programs in Biochemistry & Molecular Biology, Botany, Medical Sciences, and Zoology.
